DOCNAME: CASE OF PRICE v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
CONCLUSION: Violation of Art. 3;Non-pecuniary damage - financial award;Costs and expenses award - Convention proceedings
TEXT: CARDINAL . The applicant is CARDINAL - limb deficient as a result of phocomelia due to thalidomide . She also suffers from problems with her kidneys . On DATE , in the course of civil proceedings in ORG for recovery of a judgment debt , she refused to answer questions put to her concerning her financial position and was committed to prison for DATE for contempt of court . In the applicant 's recollection , the judge ordered that she should be taken directly to FAC . Before leaving the court the applicant asked a court officer if she could take the battery charger for her wheelchair with her . She alleges that the officer told her that this would be considered a luxury item and that she would not , therefore , be able to bring it .

CARDINAL . Because the applicant 's case had been heard during TIME DATE , it was not possible to take her to prison until DATE and she spent TIME in a cell in FAC . This cell , which contained a wooden bed and a mattress , was not specially adapted for a disabled person . The applicant alleges that she was forced to sleep in her wheelchair since the bed was hard and would have caused pain in her hips , that the emergency buttons and light switches were out of her reach , and that she was unable to use the toilet since it was higher than her wheelchair and therefore inaccessible .

CARDINAL . The custody record states that on arrival , at TIME , the applicant informed the custody officer that she suffered from kidney trouble and a recurring ear infection but that she did not require any medication or to see a doctor at that time . At TIME she declined a meal and a hot drink . At TIME the applicant said she was cold so the officer wrapped her in CARDINAL blankets . When she was checked on again at TIME the applicant was still complaining of being cold . At TIME , since she was still cold and had a headache caused by the cold , another blanket was wrapped around her . She was offered a hot drink which she refused . The applicant was asleep at TIME , but by TIME she was awake again , complaining about the cold , and again refused a hot drink . At TIME she asked to see a doctor , who arrived at TIME The doctor 's note of his examination of the applicant at TIME states :

“ Patient complained of feeling cold , headache and queasy ( no food since DATE offered but refused ) . Talking quite sensibly , not obviously hypothermia , seated in wheelchair . Tells me unable to lie flat and sleeps on sofa , sitting up , at home . On Erythromycin for ear infection . On examination ears PERSON . Unfortunately the facilities available in the cells for this type of disabled person ( sic ) . Really requires a room temp in the high CARDINAL 's as not moving / not able to move around . Insulated with ' space blanket ' and extra blankets . Offered / given Paracetamol and [ bn ] stemetil as no co - proxamol available . ”

CARDINAL . According to the custody record , the applicant slept until TIME , when she was moved to another cell and offered food and drink , which she refused . At TIME she was taken to ORG , GPE , where she was detained until TIME DATE .

CARDINAL . The applicant was not placed in a normal cell in FAC , but was instead detained in the prison 's health care centre . Her cell had a wider door for wheelchair access , handles for the disabled in the toilet recess and a hydraulic hospital bed . On arrival at the prison the applicant completed a medical questionnaire . She stated that she had health worries but that they were “ under control – takes it as it comes ” . Staff PERSON , who countersigned the questionnaire , wrote :

“ Admitted into hospital mainly for mobility problems . Inmate has thalidomide and uses an electric wheelchair which would be difficult to use in the main prison due to steps e.g. to dining room . Has not brought chair charger with her as she says police would n't let her .

She suffers from urological problems and has intermittent renal failure ... Is able to feed herself if food is cut up , is able to use cup . Manages on and off the toilet to ORG [ pass urine ] but will need assistance with ORG [ opening bowels ] in order to clean herself .

Usually sleeps on a couch at home and her dog helps her up during TIME . Will need assistance here during TIME to get off bed to use the toilet . Will try to use the hospital bed with backrest out . Contacted Dr PERSON re help for night nurse . Memo done to ORG and Security re assistance at TIME and need to unlock ...
She is allergic to many antibiotics ... Needs frequent changes of clothes due to urinary problems .
Has settled into unit and eaten dinner .
PS : Can not be lifted in normal fashion as she has a persistently dislocated shoulder due to an old injury . ”
CARDINAL . NORP The applicant was examined by PERSON , whose notes stated :
“ New reception .
Thalidomide victim with numerous deformities including absent arms upper / lower with dislocating L shoulder and no use in R upper limb . Both lower limbs are absent with small feet .
Bladder – is unable to empty completely and gets frequent retentions ( when she needs catheterisation ) and infection ...
Bowels – ... unable to manually clean herself .
At home she is relatively independent tho ' has numerous services including electric wheelchair DATE which may need recharging MONEY [ weekend ] .
In hospital has difficulty with
bed – too high
sink – unable to reach
mobility – battery running down
fluid intake – likes to take juice and there is none
diet – vegetarian
general hygiene – needs help ...
Needs : fluid intake
batteries recharged
adequate temperature ... ”
CARDINAL . A “ continuous medical record ” on the applicant was kept during her detention . The first entry , dated DATE , stated :

“ I asked duty Governor , PERSON , to give permission for a battery charger for PERSON 's wheelchair to be brought in if we could arrange it . He agreed to this and whilst here we pointed out the numerous problems staff may encounter with this inmate i.e.

( CARDINAL ) Needs lifting in and out of bed and she says this is usually done by CARDINAL person standing behind her with arms around her midriff then lifting her either onto the bed or onto her wheelchair .

( CARDINAL ) She has , at home , a device worked by compression that gets her in and out of the bath . If she does n't have a DATE bath she risks developing sores , especially where her foot lies across her ' leg ' .

( CARDINAL ) Because of recurrent urinary infections she should take QUANTITY of fluid daily but usually has juice and does n't like water , therefore will probably reduce her fluid intake . After some consideration Mr PERSON decided that if we could find PERSON a suitable place in outside hospital he would licence her to go , but we do not have any medical condition to admit her to hospital with . PERSON will review PERSON DATE , as he thinks there is a likelihood she will develop a UTI [ urinary tract infection ] . ”
CARDINAL . The nurses who cared for the applicant during her detention kept a contemporaneous record , which stated for TIME QUANTITY DATE :

“ Impossible to toilet during TIME . Have been into PERSON 's cell twice . Took TIME to toilet her then could not get her back on the bed . Given analgesia and she is getting a great deal of pain through lying on a solid mattress . Very difficult to care for her with CARDINAL nurse . ”

CARDINAL . The applicant alleged that on TIME of QUANTITY DATE she was lifted onto the toilet by a female prison officer , but was then left sitting on the toilet for TIME until she agreed to allow a male nursing officer to clean her and help her off the toilet . The Government submitted that on DATE there was only one female nurse on duty , ORG , and that she enlisted the help of CARDINAL male members of staff , Senior Officer PERSON and Officer PERSON , and that the CARDINAL male members of staff assisted ORG in sitting the applicant up and then left the room while the applicant moved her bowels . ORG then cleaned the applicant and laid her back down . It is unclear from the ORG 's submissions whether Senior Officer PERSON and Officer PERSON were nursing staff or whether they were prison officers without nursing qualifications . The applicant further claimed that TIME , a female nurse who was assisting her onto the toilet removed her bedclothes in the presence of CARDINAL male prison nursing officers , thereby exposing her , naked from the chest down , to the male officers . The Government denied that these incidents occurred . They pointed out that prior to her release the applicant made a complaint to the prison governor concerning the lack of adequate facilities , but containing no mention of the above events .
CARDINAL . An agency nurse was employed to care for the applicant during TIME to DATE . The entries in the nursing record for CARDINAL DATE stated :

“ Says she finds bed uncomfortable and there is a risk of her developing bed sores , but she is not completely immobile and is able to shift her weight about the bed . No problems with diet but fluid intake diminished due to her not liking water . There is a need for us to separate PERSON 's little whims from her genuine problems .
Bowels opened , says she 's in retention and has not PU'd [ passed urine ] since TIME , refusing to drink water , refuses to get ready for bed until TIME
Night – CARDINAL.CARDINAL asked to be put to bed . When asked why she was not in bed says day staff said agency nurse was going to wash her and put her to bed .
CARDINAL asked to be moved as she was having pains in ' legs ' . PERSON given and sat up . Settled and slept later . Has not ORG . Has been drinking . ”

CARDINAL . The remission provisions in sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of LAW DATE meant that the applicant had only to serve CARDINAL the sentence imposed , namely , DATE . Prior to her release , on DATE , the applicant was examined by PERSON who found she needed catheterising due to urine retention . The medical record stated :
“ For release TIME as soon as transport arrangements can be made . ...
To have bath and bladder emptied via catheter before leaving .
When asked if she had any specific medical complaints – she only asked for a bath and to be catheterised .

She had some complaints about her sleeping arrangements . PERSON that PERSON . PERSON had said that she could sleep on a chair and have her cell door open all night . Given that she is due for release DATE she said her Governor 's application was immaterial . ... ”

CARDINAL . The applicant was collected from prison by a friend . She claimed to have suffered health problems for DATE as a result of her treatment in detention , but has not provided direct medical evidence in support of this claim .

CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant consulted solicitors with a view to bringing an action in negligence against ORG . She was granted legal aid , limited to obtaining evidence and seeking counsel 's opinion as to merits and quantum . In his opinion dated DATE , her counsel referred to the difficulties which the applicant was likely to face in proving that she had suffered the ill - treatment which she alleged , and referred to a judgment of ORG ( ORG and ORG and Another [ DATE ] CARDINAL All England Law Reports CARDINAL ) which held that , given the lack of resources , the standard of care required of a prison hospital was lower than that which would be required in an equivalent outside institution . Counsel advised that , in the light of this case - law and the difficulties of proof which she faced , the applicant had a limited prospect of success in her claim and that , even if successful , damages were not likely to exceed MONEY . In the light of this advice , the applicant 's legal aid certificate was discharged on DATE .

CARDINAL . It is not normal practice for ORG to give any direction as to where a particular defendant should be detained . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)-(CARDINAL ) of FAC provides that it is for the Secretary of ORG to allocate a prisoner to any prison :
“ CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) A prisoner , whether sentenced to imprisonment or committed to prison on remand or pending trial or otherwise , may be lawfully confined in any prison .

( CARDINAL ) Prisoners shall be committed to such prisons as the Secretary of ORG may from time to time direct , and may by the direction of the Secretary of ORG be removed during the term of their imprisonment from the prison in which they are confined to any other prison . ”
